SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

org.gerstner.oauth2android
Class OAuth

java.lang.Object
  org.gerstner.oauth2android.OAuth

public class OAuth
extends java.lang.Object

The OAuth Object is the "control center" for all steps within the OAuth-flow. The client application only needs one instance of this class to be able to make all OAuth related requests.
To be able to make all requests it is essential to initialize the OAuth object completely. After initialization all requests can be made as described in the service providers API
See the examples below to get a basic understanding on the OAuth flow and how to use the OAuth-Object

 Example flow

 
 OAuth myOAuth = new OAuth( Server myServer, Client myClient, TokenTypeDefinition tokenType );
  myOAuth.returnAuthorizationRequestUri();                     // call this website with a browser to get the authorization
  myOAuth.executeAccessTokenRequest( "authorizationCode" );    // code from the website
  myOAuth.executeProtectedResourceRequest( Server.resourceServer url, parameterList );
 

 Detailed Example

 The server has the following API endpoints (read your service providers
 documentation for more information):

   authorization server: "https://login.example.com"
   resource server: "https://www.example.com/resources"

 The service provider issues the following client credentials (after
 registering the application):

   client id = "abc"
   client secret = "def"

 To be read in the service providers documentation:
  - for authorization from the resource owner the provider issues an AUTHORIZATION CODE
  - for authorizing towards the provider the server expects a BEARER Token
  - the redirection uri for applications: oob

 Instantiation of the OAuth object:

 
 Server myServer = new Server("https://login.example.com", "https://login.example.com", "https://www.example.com");
  Client myClient = new Client("abc", "def", "oob");
  OAuth myOAuth   = new OAuth( myServer, myClient, new BearerTokenTypeDefinition() );
 

 How to get the authorization from the resource owner:

 
 String uri = myOAuth.returnAuthorizationRequestUri();
 
 call this uri with an external user agend (web browser) and get the authorization code. 
 Then request the access token:
 
 String authorizationCode = "xyz";
 myOAuth.executeAccessTokenRequest( authorizationCode );
 
 the uri where the specific resources are:
 "https://www.example.com/resources/me/myPhotos"

 the part needed: "/me/myPhotos"

 the parameters needed for the request:
 photo="1.jpg"
 action="delete"

 prepare the list of parameters:

 
 List<NameValuePair> parameterList = new ArrayList<NameValuePair>();
  parameterList.add( new BasicNameValuePair( "photo","1.jpg" ));
  parameterList.add( new BasicNameValuePair( "action","delete" ));
 
 the actual request:
 
 myOAuth.executeProtectedResourceRequest( "/me/myPhotos", parameterList );

Author:
Christoph Gerstner
See Also:
Server, Client, TokenTypeDefinition

Field Detail

scope

private java.lang.String[] scope
The scope is an array of Strings containing all scopes of the access request. The scope describes the access range of a request. The value is defined by the authorization server (see the service providers API documentation for more details). There can be only one value for the scope or multiple, the order is not relevant.

server

private Server server
The server contains all URLs and additional informations on the service providers servers. See the service providers documentation for more details.

client

private Client client
The client contains all informations on the client application as for example the client id or the access tokens. See the service providers documentation for more details.

state

private java.lang.String state
Opaque value used by the client to maintain state between the request an callback.

tokenTypeDefinition

private TokenTypeDefinition tokenTypeDefinition
Definition of the token type issued by the authorization server. Tokens can have different kinds of types, as there are two that are supported by this library: BEARER and MAC. Since the type of the token defines the tokens parameters and how to use them, the TokenTypeDefinition provides the methods to handle the different kinds of tokens.

See Also:
BearerTokenTypeDefinition, MacTokenTypeDefinition

scopeDivider

private char scopeDivider
Flag indicating which character the service provider uses to divide the single scopes in the request. OAuth2.0 defines in its specifications that the whitespace character ought to be used. However it might happen that some service providers expect a different character. By default this flag is set to whitespace;

Constructor Detail

OAuth

public OAuth(Server server,
             Client client,
             TokenTypeDefinition tokenTypeDefinition)
Constructs an OAuth-Object that handles the OAuth specific authorization process for all outgoing an incoming communications. Each OAuth-Object handles one Client and one service provider (Server) the Client connects to.

Parameters:
server - URLs and configurations of the service provider
client - application specific configurations given by the service provider
tokenTypeDefinition - the type of tokens a service provider uses (e.g. Bearer, MAC)
See Also:
Client, Server, TokenTypeDefinition

Contact the service provider for more information.

getScope

public java.lang.String[] getScope()
Returns an array of Strings containing all scopes the access token is valid for.

Returns:
String[] of scopes for the access

getScopeString

private java.lang.String getScopeString()
Returns a single string containing all strings of the scope array, divided by a whitespace or a similar scope divider (scopeDivider). This method is especially useful when sending the scope in a request to the provider.

Returns:
String containing all scopes

setScope

public void setScope(java.lang.String[] scope)
Sets a scope for the intended request an the requested AccessToken for this request. The scope describes what resources the application may access. For more information see the specifications of the service provider.
In general a scope is an array of strings, where each string describes one scope "area". To add only one single scope string one can use addScope(String);
This method overrides all existing scopes set before.

Parameters:
scope - String[] of single scope Strings

addScope

public void addScope(java.lang.String scope)
Adds a scope to the intended request an the requested AccessToken for this request. The scope describes what resources the application may access. For more information see the specifications of the service provider.
In general a scope is an array of strings, where each string describes one scope "area". To set all scope strings at ones one can use setScope(String[]); If no scope was set before and the scope array is empty a new array is created. Otherwise this single scope String is added to the end of that array.

Parameters:
scope - a single scope String

getScopeDivider

public char getScopeDivider()
Returns the character used to divide the scopes. The default setting for this flag is whitespace.

Returns:
char used to divide the scopes
See Also:
scopeDivider

setScopeDivider

public void setScopeDivider(char scopeDivider)
Sets the character that should be used to divide the scopes. The default setting for this flag is whitespace.

Parameters:
scopeDivider - char that divides two scopes
See Also:
scopeDivider

prepareAuthorizationRequest

private java.util.List<NameValuePair> prepareAuthorizationRequest()
Prepares the authorization request with the previously specified parameters in an appropriate way for a http request to get an authorization code considering the OAuth 2.0 specification.

Returns:
List prepared list of parameters

returnAuthorizationRequestUri

public java.lang.String returnAuthorizationRequestUri()
Returns a url including all parameters needed to ask the authorization server for the resource owners grant. Direct this url to a user agent capable of displaying web sites in a human readable manner.

Returns:
S string representation of the url to pass to a web browser.

prepareAccessTokenRequest

private java.util.List<NameValuePair> prepareAccessTokenRequest()
Prepares the request for an Access-Token by filling the parameters list with the needed parameters, e.g the client_id or grant_type.
It can be used for all authorization methods.

Returns:
List of NameValuePairs containing the parameters for the request.
See Also:
executeAccessTokenRequest(), executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List), executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String), executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List), executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.List)

getTokens

private Response getTokens(java.util.List<NameValuePair> parameter)
                    throws InvalidRequestException,
                           InvalidTokenTypeException,
                           InvalidClientException,
                           InvalidGrantException,
                           UnauthorizedClientException,
                           UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                           InvalidScopeException,
                           OAuthException,
                           java.io.IOException
Finds the access token and the refresh token (if any) in the Response returned by the request. This method is called by any executeAccessTokenRequest. Since this method handles a Response Instance an OAuth specific exception might be thrown if the request is invalid or has errors of any kind.
To catch all Exceptions at once, catch OAuthException, otherwise a concrete error handling is possible by catching single exceptions.

Parameters:
parameter - all parameters for the request included in a List
Returns:
Response instance for further use
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - parent class of all OAuth specific exceptions above
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request
See Also:
executeAccessTokenRequest(), ErrorParser

executeAccessTokenRequest

public Response executeAccessTokenRequest()
                                   throws InvalidRequestException,
                                          InvalidTokenTypeException,
                                          InvalidClientException,
                                          InvalidGrantException,
                                          UnauthorizedClientException,
                                          UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                          InvalidScopeException,
                                          OAuthException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Executes the Request for an Access-Token by transmitting the client credentials only. This method is used only under specific circumstances e.g. when the client is the actual resource owner of the resources he wants to access with the requested access token. The access token and the refresh token (if any) are automatically assigned to the client instance. See the OAuth 2.0 specification for more details.
Under normal circumstances one might call the executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) method.

Other methods are:
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List) - transmitting only the client credentials but with a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) - used under normal circumstances to get an access token with the authorization code
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the authorization code but with additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String) - used to transmit the users password credentials directly
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the users password credentials directly but with additional parameters

Returns:
Response containing the AccessToken or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request

executeAccessTokenRequest

public Response executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List<NameValuePair> additionalParameter)
                                   throws InvalidRequestException,
                                          InvalidTokenTypeException,
                                          InvalidClientException,
                                          InvalidGrantException,
                                          UnauthorizedClientException,
                                          UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                          InvalidScopeException,
                                          OAuthException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Executes the Request for an Access-Token by transmitting the client credentials and additional parameters. This method is used only under specific circumstances e.g. when the client is the actual resource owner of the resources he wants to access with the requested access token. The access token and the refresh token (if any) are automatically assigned to the client instance. See the OAuth 2.0 specification for more details.
Under normal circumstances one might call the executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) method.

Other methods are:
  • executeAccessTokenRequest() - transmitting only the client credentials but without a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) - used under normal circumstances to get an access token with the authorization code
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the authorization code but with additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String) - used to transmit the users password credentials directly
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the users password credentials directly but with additional parameters

Parameters:
additionalParameter - user defined parameters for the request (see the service providers API documentation)
Returns:
Response containing the AccessToken or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request

executeAccessTokenRequest

public Response executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String authorizationCode)
                                   throws InvalidRequestException,
                                          InvalidTokenTypeException,
                                          InvalidClientException,
                                          InvalidGrantException,
                                          UnauthorizedClientException,
                                          UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                          InvalidScopeException,
                                          OAuthException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Executes the Request for an Access-Token by transmitting the authorization code with additional parameters. This method is normally used. The access token and the refresh token (if any) are automatically assigned to the client instance. See the OAuth 2.0 specification for more details.


Other methods are:
  • executeAccessTokenRequest() - transmitting only the client credentials but without a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List) - transmitting only the client credentials but with a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the authorization code but with additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String) - used to transmit the users password credentials directly
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the users password credentials directly but with additional parameters

Returns:
Response containing the AccessToken or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request

executeAccessTokenRequest

public Response executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String authorizationCode,
                                          java.util.List<NameValuePair> additionalParameter)
                                   throws InvalidRequestException,
                                          InvalidTokenTypeException,
                                          InvalidClientException,
                                          InvalidGrantException,
                                          UnauthorizedClientException,
                                          UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                          InvalidScopeException,
                                          OAuthException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Executes the Request for an Access-Token by transmitting the authorization code. This method is normally used. The access token and the refresh token (if any) are automatically assigned to the client instance. See the OAuth 2.0 specification for more details.


Other methods are:
  • executeAccessTokenRequest() - transmitting only the client credentials but without a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List) - transmitting only the client credentials but with a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) - used under normal circumstances to get an access token with the authorization code
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String) - used to transmit the users password credentials directly
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the users password credentials directly but with additional parameters

Parameters:
additionalParameter - user defined parameters for the request (see the service providers API documentation)
Returns:
Response containing the AccessToken or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request

executeAccessTokenRequest

public Response executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String username,
                                          java.lang.String password)
                                   throws InvalidRequestException,
                                          InvalidTokenTypeException,
                                          InvalidClientException,
                                          InvalidGrantException,
                                          UnauthorizedClientException,
                                          UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                          InvalidScopeException,
                                          OAuthException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Executes the Request for an Access-Token by transmitting the resource owners password credentials (username and password). This method should only be used under special circumstances and with great care. The access token and the refresh token (if any) are automatically assigned to the client instance. See the OAuth 2.0 specification for more details.


Other methods are:
  • executeAccessTokenRequest() - transmitting only the client credentials but without a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List) - transmitting only the client credentials but with a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) - used under normal circumstances to get an access token with the authorization code
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the authorization code but with additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the users password credentials directly but with additional parameters

Returns:
Response containing the AccessToken or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request

executeAccessTokenRequest

public Response executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String username,
                                          java.lang.String password,
                                          java.util.List<NameValuePair> additionalParameter)
                                   throws InvalidRequestException,
                                          InvalidTokenTypeException,
                                          InvalidClientException,
                                          InvalidGrantException,
                                          UnauthorizedClientException,
                                          UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                          InvalidScopeException,
                                          OAuthException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Executes the Request for an Access-Token by transmitting the resource owners password credentials (username and password) and additional parameters. This method should only be used under special circumstances and with great care. The access token and the refresh token (if any) are automatically assigned to the client instance. See the OAuth 2.0 specification for more details.


Other methods are:
  • executeAccessTokenRequest() - transmitting only the client credentials but without a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.util.List) - transmitting only the client credentials but with a List of additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String) - used under normal circumstances to get an access token with the authorization code
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List) - also to transmit the authorization code but with additional parameters
  • executeAccessTokenRequest(java.lang.String, java.lang.String) - used to transmit the users password credentials directly

Parameters:
additionalParameter - user defined parameters for the request (see the service providers API documentation)
Returns:
Response containing the AccessToken or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request

executeProtectedResourceRequest

public Response executeProtectedResourceRequest(java.lang.String requestUri,
                                                java.util.List<NameValuePair> parameter,
                                                java.lang.String httpMethod)
                                         throws InvalidRequestException,
                                                InvalidClientException,
                                                InvalidGrantException,
                                                UnauthorizedClientException,
                                                UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                                InvalidScopeException,
                                                OAuthException,
                                                java.io.IOException,
                                                InvalidTokenTypeException
Executes a request for the protected resources.
The request is directed to the given url of the Resource-Server, where as the resource endpoint directs the request to the specified resource. Additional parameters can be defined to specify the request (see the service providers API documentation for more details. If the request does not require the use of the http POST method, see Connection for other standard methods.

Parameters:
requestUri - string containing the part of the url that leads to the resource
parameter - list with additional parameters to specify the resource
httpMethod - string that specifies the http method that should be used (e.g. GET, POST...)
Returns:
Response containing the requested Resources or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request
InvalidTokenTypeException - if the specified token is not of the type the server expects
See Also:
executeProtectedResourceRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List)

executeProtectedResourceRequest

public Response executeProtectedResourceRequest(java.lang.String requestUri,
                                                java.util.List<NameValuePair> parameter)
                                         throws InvalidRequestException,
                                                InvalidClientException,
                                                InvalidGrantException,
                                                UnauthorizedClientException,
                                                UnsupportedGrantTypeException,
                                                InvalidScopeException,
                                                OAuthException,
                                                java.io.IOException,
                                                InvalidTokenTypeException
Executes a request for the protected resources.
The request is directed to the given url of the Resource-Server, where as the resource endpoint directs the request to the specified resource. Additional parameters can be defined to specify the request (see the service providers API documentation for more details.

Parameters:
requestUri - string containing the part of the url that leads to the resource
parameter - list with additional parameters to specify the resource
httpMethod - string that specifies the http method that should be used (e.g. GET, POST...)
Returns:
Response containing the requested Resources or an error message from the server.
Throws:
InvalidRequestException - the request is missing a parameter or is otherwise invalid
InvalidTokenTypeException - the server did not specify which token type to expect or the wrong token type was received.
InvalidClientException - the client could not be identified
InvalidGrantException - the authorization grant is not valid
UnauthorizedClientException - the token is not valid or is of the wrong type
UnsupportedGrantTypeException - the client used an unsupported method for the authorization grant
InvalidScopeException - the scope is incomplete or invalid
OAuthException - if this is catched, no other OAuthException extending Exception will be thrown.
java.io.IOException - a connection error occurred during the request
InvalidTokenTypeException - if the specified token is not of the type the server expects
See Also:
#executeProtectedResourceRequest(java.lang.String, java.util.List, java.lang.string)
